parts.text: Hello my name is Catherine Parker and I am going to have a conversation with Gail
Adams for visible lives oral histories of the disability
experience for the New York Public Library. The date is January third two
thousand and fifteen and I am at the New York Public Library
offices in midtown Manhattan and again at
her home in Columbus Ohio. So
Gail can you tell me about where you come from.
OK My name is Gail Adam and I was born in
Bremerton Washington in one thousand nine hundred eighty four.
I was a navy.
I was what they call a maybe brat
. I
moved to a higher what I would to. Start we move the plane
And I know what you're the small tail. And
We lived there for a while and then we came. Up here and I came to
Columbus.
I've been here in Columbus ever since.
OK Can you tell me about like what your childhood was like
. Well.
You know with. Challenges.
First of all I had.
My mom and dad were really. Not sure what to do about
. My blindness and when they were in that handle
. So. To be out of a place
called the vision center. And they had a family support group
and. They. Wanted to
Know You know how different how other people handled their kid
who are blind. My parents found out that I was blind.
My mom said that I wasn't tracking like I should. And I
want to buy a wing. And. So they took me to the doctor and they
found out that I had.
Optic Nerve dysplasia. In other words my optic nerve
failed to develop. So that's how. That's why they. Are
. The cause of my blindness thing. So
. When I was growing up I
learned Braille. I had a lot of melt down as
most kids do. I didn't want to get my my
parents were trying to get me to get my balance
. Corrected because when you're when you're blind
you're bouncing dog so the best way to do that if you use a
balance beam. And I did not want to get up on
that thing. I was just going to tell no I didn't want to do it and my mom
she came to school one day and. She caught me in one of my
meltdowns Oh boy that was a real bummer though
but I have I have a younger sibling named Eric
And he is. I'm. My mom said
no more after that but. We had a pretty a pretty
good childhood. I think my parents did the best they could
to. Help me. With certain things
. It was. We had fun times and
we. Also had some times of frustration
About it. Can you tell me about more about
the ways that you were supported.
Well. We also had the we not only had the vision
center but we also had.
A. Caseworker named Neal Murphy who came
out to visit me.
And. I can't remember I remember him I mean I
remember him and he
was really nice he was really neat really nice man and we talking
About things. But the Lions Club was
also a supporter. They helped me get my first boiler
. So that was a nice treat I had that for
thirty years while close to forty. It was a good whaler.
And.
For people who don't know including the what prayer
a braille or Braille on a profile of Braille or yeah
it's a machine that looks like a little pipe lighter and has the keys
on it because Braille to think about them. And it
has a space bar in the middle and then it's got a back they key in the right
and then advance key on the left and got a carriage and a
platen. If you will the paper in and you can type.
It's a pretty good pretty heavy machine about about ten pounds.
And. But you can type. On
. Braille and its Braille paper it kind of it thicker
than typing paper.
It's almost like you know if you think of it that way like
a manila folder. But that's. And cardstock it
kind of reminds you of cardstock but a little thinner and a guard dog but not quite
. But that's. There's they comes in
two different sizes eight by eleven and eleven by eleven. And you can get
it either in notebook with the whole of punched in an already or
you can get it without you can punch them yourself and
. They prefer you use that. Rather than
. Typing on a regular sheet of paper or
a braille or as. I've used it a lot in school and
. It sure beats a flight in SA I
mean the flight style isn't good for. Writing a
short note from things in the flight and style is to make the.
Make everybody wear that medal or two pieces of metal welded
together at one end. There to strip and they have
the pen. Some of them are longer than others some of them are
pocket what they call pocket plate. And they have little.
On one side. You're going to have a one on one piece of
metal there's a little window like thing and they're shaped like a
rectangle that's where the Braille fell. OK I'm on the other side if what you
feel is a Braille cell and you put this in
between you put a paper piece of paper in between the two threads and you
snap it together and you have the little stylus it's a little
. Little what I've got a wooden knob. Some of them have a
wooden knob foam have a plastic one. It's got a sharp.
Pin that you poke in in the floor window or the
Braille felt it what you do is you just
. You if you if you want to write a short note somebody
that's what you do but really the Braille writer I think so.
OK So can you tell me more about what So you're talking at the Lions Club
and some other support used
Well the Lion Club was really good. And also at
school when I went to school.
Well I had I had a special education.
I went there for a while I went to broadly elementary school and they had a special education program
there. And. I went there for five years
and then. Then I went to Deshler
Elementary which is. We move done on the south
side that one. When I was. About twelve
years old I was going in the sixth grade. And.
Went to the chiller Deshler elementary I hated that
. But I
had I had no other choice. I walked to school with a friend of mine
and. It wasn't bad but it wasn't I.
I didn't particularly like it but we had a I had an itinerant teacher
. And what that person is is a.
They. Travel from school to school
. They have like I guess they have a list of schools that
they go to in their student each student has
. Well. What the
I Can one teacher does is they transcribe it like they have the
student write their papers and Braille. They transcribe underneath
what they write and print what's in braille so they have to sight read Braille. They have to
read it but I thought. That one of the main things
that they have to know Braille. And off
though when there's a test given me I can't teacher
is the one who. Helps out with that
. So they. Get
reports from up there in the loop. They'd be there in the loop when it comes to
the teachers and things like that. If a teacher says
well she hasn't been done very well in school I don't know what to do
about it you know and she's not applying herself in class and all that.
Teacher kind of helps out with that in the field that. Communication on to the parents
if necessary. That wasn't very fun doing that. But. You.
Know what you know it was not. But anyway
. So then when I went to school and most
Mohawk for three years and that was we had a what they called a
resource room and that was. Where a lot of
people came to have their work. Either read to them or
they can do it or they could have a study hall in the reef's resource room
. And. So that Kennedy
met with. That. How that went out for. When I went to the Mohawk
then I went to brig high school for three years
and then. Again I had the itinerant teacher
and that worked out pretty good.
No. But I had other
. You know my parents would work with the teacher and they say why didn't
she didn't she get names in Spanish but not to get these in math than
you need I need to do a little bit better with her you need to know her a little more
with me with really not make sense.
So anyway that a sort of school
support went
. Can you tell me about what you would like
for you going to school where there are other
kids that were also blind.
Well it wasn't always like that. During the first five
years of my education. Of course I went to preschool
too but that was it was just to. Get me
exposed to school and things but anyway during when I went to broadly
I went I think I told you we were there with a special
education program or about ten of us.
With the clock anyway. The
parent or the kid that will. There's about ten of us
and with it and that class and but
there were there were quite a few have to do a blind when I went to prom like now
when I went to death or I was the only blind student there and while
it was a bomber and I take my bio I earned and I know I didn't mean to
do it but you know when your arm when you're walking and you
explain your arms and I had my brain a lighter with me because I had to change classes
and. I accidently whacked people in the knees with
him a little like a bag so that was a real
gun on me and they'd say a few words that weren't very nice to say.
But I think what do you mean I'm sorry I hit you in the knee with my brain or
head and thing with. Now when I went to Mohawk
for it was the same thing and same thing in high school. So during the
first five years that with the. Now and the only
time I didn't go to the I think school for the blind for a summer
program when I was ten. And they
had a daily living skills. Classroom they had
from other classes and we did a lot of fun things together but it was
kind of it was just during the summers. So.
Anyway that yeah right
and that was the way it was being the way the thing is
what it was like for me being the only blind there.
I tried not to let it bother me. Because I figured well it's just the
way it is. So sometimes I have to
let people or not smack them but you know let them know you don't you don't talk to
me that way. Just got a lot of No that's not what you do
so I didn't have to do that very often.
Do you have any best friends.
Oh yes I had some really good friends from school
in fact in high school. I
went to my twenty class train and met some of my best friends there and
. Hang out with
them so I was not the most popular kid in school of course but
and I never did go to the senior prom. It was raining really care
. Just a bunch of hoopla anyway
so it didn't bother me any.
And I was there I was there for studying I didn't care about going and hanging
out with other friends though I did have good friends though and
I just lost touch with them and. No
. I haven't seen I would meet him from time to time
If I was in green they'd say hi Galen remember me.
Greg or I don't remember he used to go to school together I'm going oh
OK then. Yeah I remember you
well I am but I did go to my twentieth class reunion in
my thirty if I didn't go to that. I don't know I am.
I just I never did get a.
A. Postcard thing so I
thought well not to worry about it.
When. You tell me what.
Sorry that way again
. Yeah. Can you
so you just you weren't really concerned with socializing in
high school or what can you tell me more about what that was like for you
I. Didn't really have. A whole lot
. I just want to go now.
Far as extra curricular activities work and learn
. I did participate in one and that was the
morning announcement came. In that was really neat.
If. You had to audition. And I thought it was really nice
because. What you do you mean the principal's office
. There are three of us. Well if the press seen
. One of my good friends in two other
Me Myself and Debbie Payne. And all three of us would
get together and meet the principal's office and we would
they would give me the announcement for the school that morning. Sometimes there
were no announcements but. There was just only a couple that
needed to be announced and we would go to this little
. Room well
. And they had a console in there and we do our announcements from
there. I said Oh how cool this would be good for
starting out as a radio announcer and that's what I really. At first that's what I
wanted to do in film but he says no no you can't do
that. Like. You I want to say a few things but
. As a kid you were told to respect your elders knowledge Mullard
and know all that stuff so I mean. They were just they didn't
think it would work out too well because of me transportation being out.
He had to be early and had to go in there early and there was no way
I could get in early because of the. Way the buses ran.
So that didn't work out.
What about the Boston made it difficult.
The timing the buses you know it's the time
. You know especially if you're here if you had to get to
work on time and had to get to work in about by four and like they had to leave
the house at four you had to be on the air at five. Your bus was going to get
you down time. Because they were. But this started out at six in the morning
and you would you wouldn't be able to go
in to be really. They said well maybe it's not such a good thing. So
that's why they said. And they told me the pay wasn't very good. That
doesn't mean anything.
Oh well.
No it was just I'm not really clear
on the bus about work about
work you know.
Let me explain some job you know they say some job have
you have to be there or be there really early and
. Then the bus didn't get there on time. He had to
get you had to find something that would get you he would be able to get to work on
time.
And. You know get back home. Oh. That
was a maybe that was. I don't know.
OK So can you tell me then about what you did after high school
. Yeah.
Well. I graduated from high school I graduated
. With a four point a grade average
. And I was tapped for the National Honor Society
. A graduate in the class of one hundred fifty
. And. So I went to go to Wright State
University. And we toured the campus and I really liked it and
I had several university think that I mean the University of Dayton.
So I really like right. Well
. My parents said oh we don't have the money to send you
. And. The F.B.I. which
used to be called the F.B.I. Now your services are visually
impaired. They claim that they couldn't send me because it was out of
your out of their jurisdiction. Well. I think that
I later found that was a bunch of. Hoopla. And
they wanted to keep me here. That was that really irked me and I
. Have to tell you. We carried that with
me to this day I really wanted to go the right date. And I
couldn't go because of some bureaucratic baloney.
And so there I.
Went to Columbus Day. If we called Columbus Technical
Institute when I was going there but now I call on the state.
Community college. And they wanted me to be a computer
program computer program. I did it seemed to me that I didn't have to
do that I didn't have the they didn't give me the.
They did the counselor said well you're going to be a computer programmer like No way
. So. Then I changed my
major. And I got into medical trance a medical secretary
that's what I wanted to major as. Well they said well what about
medical transcription and going yeah OK. So I get into medical
transcription and I went to well I went to I dropped out of college.
And then graduate. Dropped out of school and went to another
place called. Goodwill Columbus and they have
classes there they teach. Certain classes and they taught word
processing. So. I learned how to use a computer
. With. Back it was jobs back then it
was. The boat track. The
very first sympathised speech program.
That's what I used and
. Then I had I had to get my typing speed up and
all that. And I was there for a couple years.
So. I then found someone who
would train me into medical transcription so I did that. And
went to call children's hospital I started working at Children's Hospital
. But before I
started working there. I worked at the epilepsy
fill. It up with the association of central Ohio. For a
while I was a receptionist. I volunteered there
. And. We. Had lots of first
like to be their support group and meeting and it was really
nice and I got to meet a lot of people and so that's pretty neat
. But. Then I found my job
at. Children's I worked there for seventeen years.
And then I worked here at home. My job without
force. So I work here at home for five years. I
hated it but it was
nice in some ways and not so nice in others.
And. Here I am right now.
Can you tell me more about being secretary.
Well.
The secretary medical secretary had worn.
I took classes in anatomy and physiology. And
which I thought was pretty neat. I had
. I had taken biology my senior year in high
school and that was really neat. It was an interesting course
. So I took biology and. Took
. It. The. Anatomy and
Physiology and then they had a brain. Their school
library had a Braille medical dictionary and I used to go
down there and read that thing. I'd love to read the dictionary I think it's so
neat. I've always loved to read
and write by parents or what do you do and
read the dictionary Oh I think it's nice to know what these words mean and where they come
from and. I'm really.
Some words I do think they're so neat where they come from the roots and
they come from Greek or Latin. So they got me a vest pocket dictionary
but it was just one of those small dictionaries but it was not small
by any means it was seven volume. But anyway the secretary thing I
had to I had to take. What else wasn't
there were some other courses but. But anatomy and physiology was the
main line. But I dropped out of school and never went back
But medical transcription of a little bit different than Secretary being
secretary because you're not on your head all day and you type reports
from doctors they dictate them over this tape.
Now it's been over the Internet. And so
I'm looking for something
new to do.
What do you what do you hope to do.
Well I was hoping to get into something
in the radio like in you know emergency
communications or something like that. And that's fine. The thought I
had that that I don't know I'm
right now I'm an amateur radio operator I got my
job my life in twenty oh nine
and I got all three of them. And right now I have my own station
. And. But that's an
avocation. Then put the notes in the pocket. But
. Anyway I thought well it would be nice to have something
radio related Well I looked and tried to find jobs that were
but I just couldn't find anything like radio operator he had to have a screen yet
she had to look at if they with you had to monitor a screen
and I can't I can't do that. So. That was out of the question. So
hopefully maybe a receptionist job
or something clerical. So that's what I hope to. Do
Is.
There anything else you want to talk about that we haven't touched upon
I don't know.
All right.
I can't think of anything right now or anything else that you need
To have me
not.
Well I am sort of wondering about like
. If you like
. On the flip side of being of receiving support
like. Or actually I wonder if there are any like
love interest in your life and you tell me about
Yeah actually I have had. You
mean any boyfriends or romantic interest
. I don't actually.
Not right now. I did have a boyfriend for a
while and he was just rush to me too. He was just he wanted to get it and
get it out in a hurry. He was throwing me along I'd said no you can't do
this.
And he just got to work so I broke up with a my do.
Told him I said it's not going to work. Russia mean you're
going from zero to sixty and I can handle it. So that had some other guy I
never had good luck with men just hate they have. The
best way it is. I don't think I'll ever get
married. Who knows
Maybe I don't talk anymore about
anything.
Now that I mean it seems like they're all I think like all the good ones are
gone. I hate if at all than that when. The
girl they want to do you know.
If you know what I mean. They want to. Roll in the hay and all that
stuff and I know I don't want to be bothered with that
So is there anything that you want to let
people know or tell people about might be listening to this. Like one
hundred years from now.
Oh boy.
I'd like to say a few things. First of all I think outside the box
just because someone tried to put you in a box.
Don't try.
To think outside the box. And especially if you if
you really and truly want to do something. Don't let somebody say
that you can't because that just makes you know that. But just
make sure you dig in your heel deeper and say oh yes I can I
can do this. I'm able to do it.
Well quite capable I just need training or whatever
. And. The thing about
Trying to. Form a warm body according to
your own bold it's not going to work.
I mean everybody has a unique mold and a need for men
. And that. We can dance to your own drum
. That's what I say dance to your own drum.
Everybody got. A good rhythm and. You know not not they got their
own rhythm. Some people don't have a some people have a flow on. Some
people are pretty fast and furious but
. They have thier own drummer so I got to say about that one.
OK Can I
get like a final question. What can you talk a bit
more about and your life how you get to your own drum.
OK.
RADIO Well radio you know they patched a mine
and. I've always wanted to get into radio
as we went back to going back to the.
Morning announcement thing it was just something that I thought was really unique
and I begin to get into radio and then finding out that.
It's a little challenging. That's why. Well I mean look life is but
what challenges. And. But radio is.
A passion of mine and I decided to
. Do something about that because it kept bugging me and bugging me
and bother me. And so that's why I got my amateur
radio license. I wanted to get in and get in. Work
. I want to learn about him or emergency communications I wanted to learn how
to. Be
professional on the air. So
I mean it was. Something that I chose to do.
Nobody told me well you're going to do this or you're going to do that but. I chose to
do that tonight. I love it. It's something
that. You know whenever whenever something hits
why I. Will be one of the ones out there.
Trying to help out when when disaster strikes. But I'm a member of the A
W R L much of the American Radio Relay League and they are. A good
support for me when. When challenges arise. So
that's pretty good.
OK Well thank you so much Gail for
participating in the project
Yeah thank you thank you very much Katherine for
interviewing me and it's been a pleasure. All right into that I think good bye
bye and have a good day.

entities.name: Catherine Parker
